executive_summary: Confectionary wholesalers contend with an increasingly competitive environment as vertically integrated companies expand their reach and operation costs mount. Consumers are reducing sugar consumption as prices climb and more individuals seek healthier eating habits. The rising price of sugar boosts purchase costs for wholesalers, who are also contending with volatile diesel prices. Passing costs to downstream buyers has become increasingly tricky as vertically integrated competitors leverage economies of scale to generate lower selling prices, and health-conscious consumers view the higher cost as an incentive to continue healthier eating habits.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Sales Weaken Amid Shifting Consumer Preferences
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Amid the pandemic's peak, consumption of sugar expanded as consumers sought comfort foods, like chocolate and other candies, during the stressful conditions; however, trends quickly reversed in the pandemic's wake, causing weakening sales. Consumers have become increasingly health-conscious, becoming more aware of the negative associations with eating sugar-dense foods, like most candy, and growing increasingly concerned with highly processed foods, like most candy products.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Costs Plague Smaller Confectionary Wholesalers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Confectionary wholesalers endure substantial operational costs, ranging from the price of goods to fuel costs. Maintaining price-based competition is almost impossible for independent distributors unaffiliated with a candy manufacturer. Big candy brands maintain substantial loyalty, so downstream buyers are eager to have such products on their shelves. Distributors are typically unable to compete with the brands' vertically integrated distribution systems and have little maneuverability in purchasing prices since the brand has increasingly less incentive to negotiate with them.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Vertically Integrated Companies Make it Increasingly Difficult
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Confectionary wholesalers compete internally with vertically integrated companies' distribution networks, which places the average wholesaler at a supreme disadvantage, as the larger brands have little incentive to distribute through them. The average wholesaler lacks the economies of scale from which vertically integrated operations benefit, so they endure far greater operational costs, forcing them to raise prices or cut into returns, a choice few larger competitors face.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Large candy brands have increasingly turned to online retail
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Large candy brands have increasingly turned to online retail channels to reach downstream buyers directly, sidestepping the large-scale distribution and retail process and forcing wholesalers to reconsider past processes.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Successful smaller confectionary wholesalers are commonly acquired
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Successful smaller confectionary wholesalers are commonly acquired by the largest distributors before they can become an effective competitor, increasing market share concentration and making it more difficult for new entrants to thrive.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The largest candy producers' distribution presences will balloon
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Market share concentration is slated to expand as vertically integrated distribution operations widen the gap between themselves and the average confectionary wholesaler, leaving little room for new competition. The percentage of business conducted online will expand, and the largest brands will increasingly bypass the distribution process entirely, selling directly to consumers and other downstream buyers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Purchase costs will ease, but technological advances will entice hefty investment
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Confectionary wholesalers are impacted by changes in the price of sugar and fuel, as the former is used throughout confectionary products, and the latter is essential for distribution. With both goods set to drop in price, wholesalers will benefit from easing purchase costs. Advancements in the widespread use of driverless vehicles will unfold, and wholesalers will be left with the decision of whether to invest in the technology relatively early or play it safe and wait.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Wholesalers will remain subject consumers' preferences
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The average confectionary wholesaler only distributes candy products, not participating in the production. When consumer preferences shift, wholesalers are at the whim of producers and must adapt to new conditions. The most successful wholesalers will diversify their product offerings to ensure they can effectively shift with changing preferences and offer brand and products favored by the market.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Health conscious trends are likely to remain
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the importance of a balanced diet and general health become even more commonplace and understood by the general public, consumers will become more health conscious and skeptical of sweets. With many health trends displaying staying power, wholesalers should make themselves aware of what attributes downstream customers are calling for the most and establish supply contracts with suitable producers.

industry_definition: Wholesalers in this industry wholesale a range of chocolate and nonchocolate candy, in addition to a range of savory snacks like nuts, popcorn and chips. Wholesalers resell these products to supermarkets, specialty confectionery retail outlets, convenience stores and vending machine operators.
key_trends: The number of vertically integrated companies is growing.
Premium confectioneries will become an even more powerful segment as nutritional awareness and consumer preferences continue to evolve.
The National Confectioners Association is the largest snack and candy trade organization by membership, currently representing over 675 confectionery manufacturing and wholesaling companies.
Chocolate products enjoy more consumer loyalty.
Nonchocolate candy has few health benefits.
Population density is key in the Mid-Atlantic region.
Since this Great Lakes has access to large ports and is located effectively in the heartland of continental America, it is a favored sales, distribution and warehousing region for wholesalers.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Because of their wide geographic dispersion and convenient locations, particularly for drivers, convenience stores satisfy a sizable portion of the daily consumption of confectionery products.
Confectionary wholesalers distribute products to various downstream retailers, including supermarkets and grocery stores, mass merchandisers, convenience stores and drug stores.
Drug stores emerged as a strong source of growth, especially for smaller wholesalers lacking contracts with larger retailers.
Confectionary wholesalers often buy and sell from one another to access markets outside their immediate geographic reach.

Confectionary wholesalers distribute to a range of other downstream markets, including restaurants, dollar stores, street vendors, college campuses, hotel gift shops, movie theaters, event spaces and more.

products_and_services.product_description: Chocolate products are the largest product segment for confectionary wholesalers. The segment is varied, ranging from basic dark and milk chocolate bars to seasonal varieties, specialty items and gift boxes.
The nonchocolate candy segment includes varieties made from substances other than chocolate, like fruit-flavored gummy candies, seasonal marshmallow and candy cane treats and many others.

The gum and mints segment includes various gum and mint products. It maintains greater stability than others as its products must be consumed on a much grander scale to produce similarly negative effects to more traditional candy.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Per capita disposable income determines an individual's ability to purchase goods or services.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Per Capita Sugar and Sweetener Consumption
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Consumer health preferences and general tastes and trends influence per capita sugar and sweetener consumption.
Sugar is critical in producing chocolate products, non-chocolate candies, gum and savory snacks.
The percentage of business conducted online represents the increasing use of the internet by consumers and businesses for services they historically demanded in person.

business_locations.location_description: The Mid-Atlantic region has high population densities because it includes major metropolitan areas like New York City and Philadelphia.
Since this region has access to large ports and is located effectively in the heartland of continental America, it is a favored sales, distribution and warehousing region for wholesalers.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The most important laws under this category include Sherman Antitrust Act, Clayton Antitrust Act and Hart-Scott-Rodino Act.
The FDA protects the public health by ensuring that food, cosmetics and nutritional supplements are safe and truthfully labeled.

barriers_points.barrier_description: New wholesalers must invest a moderate amount in capital expenses, like vehicle fleets and warehouse management equipment and vehicles.

basis_points.basis_title: Quality is important basis of competition
basis_points.basis_description: Since confectionery and snacks are discretionary food items, quality is one of the most important bases of competition.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The four largest confectionary wholesalers include the distribution offices of significant candy and snack manufacturers.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Gaining market share by targeting niche producers is difficult
concentration_points.concentration_description: New entrants and smaller wholesalers can mitigate the impact of vertically integrated companies by targeting local, niche candy producers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases from fuel to vehicles and cargo
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases from fuel to vehicles and cargo represent the most substantial cost for confectionary wholesalers.
The price of diesel has endured significant volatility in recent years, ultimately rising in cost.
With the number of confectionary distributors falling, some wholesalers have successfully passed rising costs on to downstream buyers.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Moderate capital expenses for new entrants
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: New wholesalers must invest a moderate amount in capital expenses, like vehicle fleets and warehouse management equipment and vehicles.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low rate of new patent technologies
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The rate of new patent technologies entering the industry is low.
The concentration of technologies is high in this industry.
Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Many products distributed by confectionary wholesalers are inexpensive and sold at retail counters.
Candy is a fairly unique food.
Gum and mint sales have endured fewer setbacks than nonchocolate candies.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Brand loyalty for gum and mints
volatility_points.volatility_description: Some consumers chew gum or use mints daily.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Discretionary nature of gum and mints
volatility_points.volatility_description: Many consumers view gum and mints as highly discretionary.
